items.title: Code quality: Define one lexer in *one* file
items.body:
(First contributor experience here.)

My fix for https://github.com/pygments/pygments/issues/1520 was heavily complicated by the fact that I first had to find the actual file for the HTTP lexer and it did not had "HTTP" in it's name.
Thus, the GitHub and locally file search did not work to find the lexer. Also GitHub's full-text search was not helpful, because the string `http` is of course used everywhere and in the actual lexer file not really present, _or_ at least not in a "whole-word-only" search that GItHub AFAIK does. (i.e. `HttpLexer` could not be found)
Only searching for `POST` as a thing had had to be defined there was successful. :roll_eyes: 
IMHO, that was too cumbersome.

Please, by all means, there is no need to put multiple lexers into a single file.
One file for one lexer would make it _much_ easier to find and thsu to maintain. There is no need to limit the amounts of files you use.
_If_ you want to group them, just use folders.

May also be applied to formatters or so. Did not look into whether they are affected by this problem as well.

items.title: HTTP lexer fails on HTTP/2.0 (HTTP/2 works)
items.body:
HTTP/2 defines pseudo-headers with colons:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/38471412/5008962

E.g.
```
POST /access/sdk/anonymous HTTP/2.0
:authority: example.zendesk.com

{}
```

in https://pygments.org/demo/#try

results in a bad image

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11966684/90981711-e59c4180-e562-11ea-89f7-ca3a6283521f.png)

Also reproduced locally with:
```
$ pygmentize -V       
Pygments version 2.4.2, (c) 2006-2019 by Georg Brandl.
```

items.title: [docs] [help] How to test my new lexer on the command line
items.body:
I just wrote the beginnings of a new lexer for the [Janet language](https://janet-lang.org/) and would like to test it. I couldn't find a link to a mailing list or forum, so I'm posting this here, but hopefully it can serve to not only help me but help improve the docs.

This is a lexer for the Janet programming language. My first attempt is: <https://gist.github.com/uvtc/f1fbd0d014bb3b2e60aeb0f3aaca582c>, and I have that saved as "janet_lexer.py".

I've read <https://pygments.org/docs/cmdline/> and <https://pygments.org/docs/lexerdevelopment/> but still cannot figure out how to run and test my pygments lexer on an input.janet file.

I'm on Debian GNU/Linux, and have my janet_lexer.py and input.janet together in the same directory. I have python3-pygments installed via apt, and so have the `pygmentize` command line tool installed.

It appears there's two ways to test my lexer: (1) via the command line, or (2) via a small script where I import the relevant modules and call the `highlight()` function.

I've tried command line incantations like:

    $ pygmentize -f html -o out.html -l janet_lexer.py:JanetLexer input.janet 
    Error: no lexer for alias 'janet_lexer.py:JanetLexer' found

    $ python3 -m pygments -l janet_lexer.py:JanetLexer -x input.janet
    /usr/bin/python3: No module named pygments.__main__; 'pygments' is a package and cannot be directly executed

to no avail.

Can you please tell me how to test my lexer? Once I can try it out and tweak its output, I can then submit a PR to request inclusion into Pygments to support Janet.

Thanks!

items.title: Can you add language shortnames to the documentation?
items.body:
I often look through this page <https://pygments.org/languages/> to check which languages I can use with Pygments, but it lacks an important piece of information - the short name for specifying the language.

By "short name", I mean the "language name" part after the opening fence, as shown below:

````markdown
```ruby
#  ^^^^ This part
```
````

It's too common the case that I have to iterate through the Python code in [`pygments/lexers`](https://github.com/pygments/pygments/tree/master/pygments/lexers) to determine which short name I should use. For example, it wasn't intuitive enough that the Python console session has a short name of `pycon`, when we usually don't refer to that feature with "console", but rather "REPL".

May I ask that the short names for each supported language be listed on the documentation page? As far as I am concerned, one short name for each language would be enough.

items.title: Markdown Lexer doesn't recognize strong/emph at the very beginning of the text
items.body:
Reproduce:

```python
from pygments.lexers.markup import MarkdownLexer

l = MarkdownLexer()

print(list(l.get_tokens("*bolded text*")))
# OUT: [(Token.Text, '*bolded'), (Token.Text, ' '), (Token.Text, 'text*'), (Token.Text, '\n')]

print(list(l.get_tokens(" *bolded text*")))
# OUT: [(Token.Text, ' '), (Token.Generic.Emph, '*bolded text*'), (Token.Text, '\n')]

print(list(l.get_tokens("**bolded text**")))
# OUT: [(Token.Text, '**bolded'), (Token.Text, ' '), (Token.Text, 'text**'), (Token.Text, '\n')]

print(list(l.get_tokens(" **bolded text**")))
# OUT: [(Token.Text, ' '), (Token.Generic.Strong, '**bolded text**'), (Token.Text, '\n')]
```

As shown in the code, if I add a space before the bold-ed/emph-ed text, the lexer outputs `Token.Generic.Strong` for the entire bold-ed/emph-ed phrase. 

If nothing precedes the bold-ed/emph-ed phrase, the lexer sees the phrase as regulart text and breaks down the phrase into parts.

### Environment

Python: Python 3.8.3
Pygments: 2.6.1

items.title: Supported optional and nested groups in bygroups(...)
items.body:
## Example

Say we got a language supporting the following lines:
```
declare abc.
declare abc : def.
declare abc : def        .
```

Then, I'd like to be able to use `bygroups` as follows:

```python
(r'(declare)(\s+)(\S+)(\s*)((:)(\s*)(\S+)(\s*))?(\.)', bygroups(
  Keyword,
  Name.Variable,
  Whitespace,
  (Punctuation, Whitespace, Name.Variable, Whitespace),
  Punctuation
))
```

However, with the current Pygments version I get `TypeError: 'tuple' object is not callable`, so I guess this is not supported or intended. Any plans to add support for this?

As a workaround in my lexer, I currently duplicate the lexing rule with and without the optional part.

items.title: make fails on ubuntu - python/python3 problem
items.body:
Doing a basic make on a new clone on a Ubuntu 19 OS produces this:
```
thomas:pygments$ make mapfiles
(cd pygments/formatters; python _mapping.py)
pygments.formatters.terminal256
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "_mapping.py", line 51, in <module>
    module = __import__(module_name, None, None, [''])
  File "../../pygments/formatters/terminal256.py", line 31, in <module>
    from pygments.style import ansicolors
  File "../../pygments/style.py", line 171
    class Style(metaclass=StyleMeta):
```

This appears to be due to the assumption in the Makefile that `python` should resolve to python3. This is not the usual assumption as far as I know, and won't work on any system where `python` means Python 2.x and `python3` is used as the name of Python 3.x. Some simple changes to the Makefile will fix this.

items.title: Error when applying python lexer to string containing `
items.body:
Applying the python lexer to a string containg "`" throws an error:
```
from pygments import lex
from pygments.lexers import PythonLexer

PL = PythonLexer()
PL.add_filter('raiseonerror')
l = lex("`", PL)
u = list(l)
```
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 7, in <module>
    u = list(l)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pygments/filter.py", line 20, in _apply
    for token in filter_.filter(lexer, stream):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pygments/filters/__init__.py", line 196, in filter
    raise self.exception(value)
pygments.filters.ErrorToken: `
```
This only happens the first time, so the following code doesn't crash
```
from pygments import lex
from pygments.lexers import PythonLexer

PL = PythonLexer()
l = lex("`", PL)
u = list(l)
PL.add_filter('raiseonerror')
v = list(l)
```

items.title: Pygments 2.6 identifies as Python 2 & 3
items.body:
Just did a pip install -U pygments and spotted:

`Downloading Pygments-2.6.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl`

But the release notes specify:

> Pygments 2.6 is a major new release removing support for Python 2.x.
> From Pygments 2.6, we require Python 3.5 or newer to run Pygments.

So surley this should be packaged as `Pygments-2.6.1-py3-none-any.whl` so that python 2 users _(there are still quite a few)_ will **not** get this update.

items.title: E0611 - No name <N> in module <M> - Lexers and Formatters Example
items.body:
| Component | Version |
| --- | --- |
| macOS | 10.15.2 |
| Python | 3.8.0 |
| Pylint | 2.4.4 |
| Pygments | 2.5.2 |

The import statements given in the [Introduction and Quickstart](https://pygments.org/docs/quickstart/) example result in a `E0611` flag.

```python
'''
Sample Module Docstring
'''

from pygments import highlight
from pygments.lexers import PythonLexer
from pygments.formatters import HtmlFormatter

CODE = 'print "Hello World"'
print(highlight(CODE, PythonLexer(), HtmlFormatter()))
```

```bash
************* Module main
main.py:6:0: E0611: No name 'PythonLexer' in module 'pygments.lexers' (no-name-in-module)
main.py:7:0: E0611: No name 'HtmlFormatter' in module 'pygments.formatters' (no-name-in-module)

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at -10.00/10 (previous run: -10.00/10, +0.00)
```

However, using these import statements instead seems to adhere to the `E0611` guideline.

```python
'''
Sample Module Docstring
'''

from pygments import highlight
from pygments.lexers.python import PythonLexer
from pygments.formatters.html import HtmlFormatter

CODE = 'print "Hello World"'
print(highlight(CODE, PythonLexer(), HtmlFormatter()))
```

```bash

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at 10.00/10 (previous run: 10.00/10, +0.00)
```

| Flags `E0611` | Does Not Flag `E0611` |
| --- | --- |

items.title: Better C and C++ detection
items.body:
Actually C and C++ detection/lexer guessing is based on finding some preprocessor instructions (e.g. `#include "my_header.h"` or `#ifndef MY_MACRO`), or, in case of C++, on finding the `using namespace` statement. However, many C and C++ snippets do not use preprocessor, and many C++ code do not use `using namespace` statements at all.

Nevertheless, there are many features and keywords which seem to be unique to C or C++, and which can be used for the detection of these languages.

For C detection:
  - The keywords `_Bool`, `_Complex`, `_Imaginary`, `_Generic`, `_Alignas`, `_Alignof`, `_Atomic`, `_Noreturn`, `_Static_assert`, `_Thread_local` seem to be unique to the C language.

For C++ detection:
  - The keywords `constinit`, `consteval`, `co_await`, `co_return`, `co_yield` seem to be unique to the C++ language.
  - The `concept` seem to be unique to the C++ language.

The macros `__cplusplus` (defined for the C++ language by C++ compilers), and `__STDC__` (defined by C ANSI compliant compilers), where present in code, probably guarantee that the code is written in C or C++ (it is however not possible to distinguish the two, from C++ code that can use '__STDC__', and C code that can use '__cplusplus').

In addition, we can use GNU attributes (e.g. `__attribute__((always_inline))`) or MSVC keywords (e.g. `__declspec`) for detection.

items.title: Wrong lexing for R (SLexer) in case of "." (dot) as a variable name
items.body:
Pygments version: 2.5.2 with fix `23c8748b5fa42753807a500a8b2406e1299f4e78`
Code:
```
from pygments.lexers import SLexer
print(list(SLexer().get_tokens(".<-1")))
```
Output:
```
[(Token.Name, '.<'), (Token.Literal.Number, '-1'), (Token.Text, '\n')]
```

`(Token.Name, '.<')` is actually incorrect. The whole result should be:
```
[(Token.Name, '.'), (Token.Operator, '<-'), (Token.Literal.Number, '1'), (Token.Text, '\n')]
```

P.S. This particular case is just a minimal example. Here is a real world example:
```
from pygments.lexers import SLexer
print(list(SLexer().get_tokens("mymodel = lm(gene ~ ., data = mydata)")))
```
This example is from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45655679/meaning-of-dot-in-lmy-in-r

items.title: 2.5.1 MatlabLexer regression
items.body:
https://github.com/pygments/pygments/pull/1271 introduced a regression to `MatlabLexer`.

### Reproduction script:
```
import pygments
from pygments.lexers.matlab import MatlabLexer

print(list(pygments.lex('foo bar', MatlabLexer())))
print(list(pygments.lex('foo', MatlabLexer())))
```

### Before (2.5.1 with 612fb2b reverted):
```
[(Token.Name, 'foo'), (Token.Text, ' '), (Token.Name, 'bar'), (Token.Text, '\n')]
[(Token.Name, 'foo'), (Token.Text, '\n')]
```

### After:
There are invalid characters (` `, `\n`) in `Name`. ~~Moreover, `bar` is of a wrong type now.~~
```
[(Token.Name, 'foo '), (Token.Literal.String, 'bar'), (Token.Punctuation, '\n')]
[(Token.Name, 'foo\n'), (Token.Punctuation, '')]
```

@birkenfeld @anntzer could you please have another look at those changes?

items.title: guess_lexer picks TeraTermLexer for most code samples in Pygments 2.4
API to get the current state?
items.body:
Hi, I am writing a command-line tool and using pygments to do the syntax highlighting and completion.

For the auto-completion, I need pygments to tell me the current `state`, so I can guess the next possible token, base on that, I can have a complete list.

For example, I have a redis lexer like this:

```
class RedisLexer(RegexLexer):
    name = "redis lexer"

    tokens = {
        "root": [
            (r"\s+", Whitespace),
            (r"(?i)GET", Keyword, "get"),
            (r"(?i)SET", Keyword, "set"),
        ],
        "get": [(r"\s+", Whitespace), (r"\w+", Name, "#pop")],
        "set": [(r"\s+", Whitespace), (r"\w+", Name, "value")],
        "value": [(r"\s+", Whitespace), (r"\w+", Name, "#pop:2")],
    }
```

When user type `set foo`, I want to know the current state is `"value"`.

Is there an API to do this? I searched the documents but didn't find any.

items.title: Console lexer cannot detect virtual environment names
items.body:
When a Python virtual environment is activated, by default it puts the virtual environment's name to the left of the prompt in a shell session. E.g.: ```console ~$ source myenv/bin/activate (myenv) ~$ ``` This causes Pygments to fail to detect the prompt in the `console`/`shell-session` lexer. Compare: Without the virtual environment: ```console $ pygmentize -l console -f html <<<"[~/project]$ foo -h" 
[~/project]$ foo -h
``` With the virtual environment: ```console $ pygmentize -l console -f html <<<"(env) [~/project]$ foo -h" 
(env) [~/project]$ foo -h
``` Note that it *is* detected if there is nothing after the environment name or possibly a user@host:dir without brackets: ```console $ pygmentize -l shell-session -f html <<<"(env)a@b:x$ foo -h" 
(env)a@b:x$ foo -h
``` **Context:** Some software I develop is documented with Sphinx. Since I encourage users of my software to use virtual environments, I would like to illustrate their use in my documentation, but the lexer fails to parse my examples if I use the virtual environment names. I think this is just a matter of accounting for an optional virtual environment name in BashSessionLexer._ps1rgx, but there may be complexities I'm not considering.

(Original issue 1537 created by cyrus-and on 2019-08-24T19:54:25.651180+00:00)

`get_lexer_for_filename` is so much slower than `get_lexer_by_name` even though AFAIK it only performs some string matching:

```
$ time python3 -c 'import pygments.lexers; pygments.lexers.get_lexer_for_filename("foo.c")'

real    0m0.938s
user    0m0.860s

items.title: Add Unicode Support in RTF format
items.body:
(Original issue 1532 created by moooc on 2019-07-18T05:00:22.123798+00:00)

Hi, I found a problem in RTF format when I input some Unicode characters. For example, `你好` will be ill-formatted. I've checked the code, and the solution is change the `formatters\rtf.py`:

```python
    def _escape(self, text):
        text = text.replace('\\', '\\\\') \
                   .replace('{', '\\{') \
                   .replace('}', '\\}')
        # RTF does not support UNICODE at all. We have to "Encode" them first. For example:
        # wchar_t* c=L"你好"; should be encoded to \'c4\'e3\'ba\'c3. And it is supposed to convert 
        # UNICODE to ANSI to prevent losing data. 
        import re
        return re.sub(r'([^\x00-\xff])', lambda m:
            ''.join([("\\'" + hex(c)[2:]) for c in m.group(1).encode('mbcs')]), text)
```

And the default charset should be `fcharset134`, it's originally `fcharset0`:

```python
    def format_unencoded(self, tokensource, outfile):
        # rtf 1.8 header
        outfile.write(r'{\rtf1\ansi\deff0'
                      r'{\fonttbl{\f0\fmodern\fprq1\fcharset134%s;}}'
                      r'{\colortbl;' % (self.fontface and
                                        ' ' + self._escape(self.fontface) or
                                        ''))
```

I hope you guys can update the code. Thanks!

items.body:
(Original issue 1528 created by sdrobert on 2019-06-27T18:07:19.014114+00:00)

Hi there and thanks for reading,

You can see the demo here: [http://pygments.org/demo/6846860/](http://pygments.org/demo/6846860/)

AFAICT, everything after a pound \(#\) should be considered a comment, until the end of line. Instead, Pygments parses this as a new key-value pair. You can get errors if you incorrectly specify a key-value pair.

Thanks again,  
Sean

items.body:
(Original issue 1523 created by miranska on 2019-06-06T22:56:11.168574+00:00)

Hi,  
This may be an RTFM issue, but I wonder if it is a bug or a feature. Consider this Java code snippet:

```java
String hw = "Hello, World";
```

I would expect that the `String` word would be recognized as `Type`. Instead, it is recognized as `Name`.

Here is a code snippet for the repro:

```python
from pygments import highlight
from pygments.formatters import RawTokenFormatter
from pygments.lexers.jvm import JavaLexer
src = 'String hw = "Hello, World";'
parsed_data = highlight(src, JavaLexer(), RawTokenFormatter())
print(parsed_data.decode('ascii'))
```

Output:

```
Token.Name	'String'
Token.Text	' '
Token.Name	'hw'
Token.Text	' '
Token.Operator	'='
Token.Text	' '
Token.Literal.String	'"Hello, World"'

items.title: Erlang and Elixir shell lexers don't recognize node names in prompts
items.body:
(Original issue 1521 created by yuce on 2019-06-02T07:35:53.462037+00:00)

Erlang and Elixir shell prompts may have the node name as a prefix. `lexers.ErlangShellLexer`  doesn't highlight the prompt in the text below:

```erlang
Erlang/OTP 22 [erts-10.4] [source] [64-bit] [smp:8:8] [ds:8:8:10] [async-threads:1] [hipe]

Eshell V10.4  (abort with ^G)
(e1@example.com)1> {any, c1@example.com} ! {hello, world}.
{hello,world}
(e1@example.com)2> flush().
Shell got {hello,world}
ok
```

Updating `lexers.ErlangShellLexer` fixes the issue:

```
_prompt_re = re.compile(r'(?:\([\w@_.]+\))?\d+>(?=\s|\Z)')
```

`lexers.ElixirConsoleLexer` doesn’t highlight the prompt in the following text:

```
Erlang/OTP 22 [erts-10.4] [source] [64-bit] [smp:8:8] [ds:8:8:10] [async-threads:1] [hipe]

Interactive Elixir (1.8.1) - press Ctrl+C to exit (type h() ENTER for help)
iex(c1@ichi.cs)1> IO.puts("hello!")
hello!
:ok
```

Updating `lexers.ElixirConsoleLexer` fixes the issue:

```
_prompt_re = re.compile(r'(iex|\.{3})((?:\([\w@_.]+\))?\d+|\(\d+\))?> ')
```

items.title: Change file endings for TypoScript lexer to .typoscript
items.body:
(Original issue 1498 created by sypets on 2019-02-16T22:20:26.783666+00:00)

TypoScript lexer currently uses .ts and .txt. Both are deprecated for TypoScript. Due to conflicts with textfiles and TypeScript files

See [TYPO3 Changelog](https://docs.typo3.org/typo3cms/extensions/core/Changelog/8.7.x/Feature-78161-IntroduceTypoScriptFileExtension.html)

items.title: Support copy-paste of HTML output without Token.Generic.Prompt
items.body: (Original issue 1497 created by xhochy on 2019-02-13T09:19:56.617509+00:00) In the case of using the HTMLFormatter together with the ipython lexer for formatting the following output, the leading characters are correctly formatted as `Token.Generic.Prompt`, i.e. they will be formatted as `…` in HTML. ``` In [3]: df = pd.DataFrame( ...: { ...: "A": 1., ...: "B": pd.Timestamp("20130102"), ...: "C": pd.Series(1, index=list(range(4)), dtype="float32"), ...: "D": np.array([3] * 4, dtype="int32"), ...: "E": pd.Categorical(["test", "train", "test", "train"]), ...: "F": "foo", ...: } ...: ) ``` We would like that users of our documentation can copy-paste the code examples without including the prompt part. This can be achieved by making the prompt part of the style instead of the actual text by replacing ` ...: ` with `` and a CSS definition `span.gp::before { content: attr(data-marker); }`. I would be happy to make a PR to add this as an option to the HTMLFormatter but I'm unsure what the correct approach would be to implement this.

items.title: test_cmdline fails on Python 2.7 with UnicodeDecodeError
items.body:
(Original issue 1492 created by ony on 2019-01-12T14:54:20.549984+00:00)

```
======================================================================                       
ERROR: test_L_opt (test_cmdline.CmdLineTest)                                                 
----------------------------------------------------------------------                       
Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                                                                                        
  File "/var/tmp/paludis/build/dev-python-Pygments-2.3.1/work/PYTHON_ABIS/2.7/Pygments-2.3.1/tests/test_cmdline.py", line 149, in test_L_opt
    o = self.check_success('-L')                                                                                                                                                          
  File "/var/tmp/paludis/build/dev-python-Pygments-2.3.1/work/PYTHON_ABIS/2.7/Pygments-2.3.1/tests/test_cmdline.py", line 64, in check_success
    code, out, err = run_cmdline(*cmdline, **kwds)                                                                                                                                        
  File "/var/tmp/paludis/build/dev-python-Pygments-2.3.1/work/PYTHON_ABIS/2.7/Pygments-2.3.1/tests/test_cmdline.py", line 56, in run_cmdline
    out, err = stdout_buffer.getvalue().decode('utf-8'), \                                   
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/StringIO.py", line 271, in getvalue                               
    self.buf += ''.join(self.buflist)                                                                                                                                                     
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 15: ordinal not in range(128)
                                                                                             
----------------------------------------------------------------------                       
Ran 2041 tests in 12.717s                                                                    
```
([full log](https://paste.pound-python.org/show/1QJ4buskCEVetVGBmIQ7/))

On Python 2.7 `test_cmdline` uses native `StringIO`.  Similar error can be achieved with

```python
repr(''.join(['\xc2', u'']))
```

I.e. it looks like an implicit unicode conversion because of mixed (unicode vs normal strings) writes to `stdout` in `pygments.cmdline`.

items.title: MatlabLexer cannot handle literal "function*" occurences
items.body:
(Original issue 1491 created by None on 2019-01-10T08:11:35.870765+00:00)

If the Matlab code contains a variable named ``function.*`` word anywhere which is not an actual function header, then it will be misinterpreted for example:

``` matlab
classdef ClassExample
    % function in the comment
    % _function_ in the comment
    % function_ in the comment

    methods
        function functionInTheName(obj)
            variable_function = 10;
            functionVariable = 10;
        end
    end
end
```

This causes a problem in the ``sphinxcontrib-matlab`` python package

items.title: Lexing Support for HTTP/2
items.body:
(Original issue 1486 created by ocket8888 on 2018-12-05T01:32:24.460808+00:00)

the HTTPLexer only supports HTTP/1, but HTTP/2 is quite mature and in fact most major web browsers already support HTTP/3. I'm not sure what extra work that would entail, but at the very least it shouldn't cause a failure to lex if the protocol version isn't `1.1`. For example, `HTTP/2 204\r\n\r\n` is a totally valid HTTP/2 response, but will fail to pass through the lexer (for serveral reasons).

items.title: Type hints
items.body:
(Original issue 1485 created by The-Compiler on 2018-11-26T15:24:35.119863+00:00)

I recently started using [mypy](http://mypy-lang.org/) with my [project](https://www.qutebrowser.org/) and it says *"No library stub file for module 'pygments'"* (same for `pygments.lexers` and `pygments.formatters`).

Do you have any plans to introduce type annotations for pygments? Those could be done in the code as comments, as a [separate stub file](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/stubs.html#stub-files), or (whenever Python 2 support is dropped), with a proper annotation syntax.

Also, thanks a lot for pygments! I've been using it for a while now, and never had any trouble with it.

items.title: Bazel (Skylark/Starlark) lexer
items.body:
(Original issue 1479 created by None on 2018-10-23T20:27:56.679515+00:00)

This request is very similar to issue #298.

Bazel is Google's open sourced version of their Blaze build system. Its build definitions are written in a language called Starlark (formerly Skylark). More information can be found at https://github.com/bazelbuild/starlark .

Starlark is a subset of Python, so I'd request it to be aliased to Python as was done with SCons.

Filenames and file patterns:

* WORKSPACE (all caps)
* BUILD (all caps) and BUILD.bazel
* *.bzl

items.title: rebol lexer: unclosed character class in regex
items.body:
(Original issue 1467 created by thomaswaldmann on 2018-08-16T20:21:08.215964+00:00)

https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main/src/7941677dc77d4f2bf0bbd6140ade85a9454b8b80/pygments/lexers/rebol.py#lines-242

See how it misses the backslash before the square bracket.

Compare to the regex 3 lines above that.

re module does not like that:

```
#!python
>>> text='          REBOL['
>>> re.search(r'\s*REBOL\s*[', text, re.IGNORECASE)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "env/lib/python2.7/re.py", line 146, in search
    return _compile(pattern, flags).search(string)
  File "env/lib/python2.7/re.py", line 251, in _compile
    raise error, v # invalid expression
sre_constants.error: unexpected end of regular expression
```

Issue was found by the pycharm code checker:

"unclosed character class"

Found it in 2.1.3, but it is still there in current code.

items.title: Add Spyder to list of "Who uses pygments"
items.body:
(Original issue 1465 created by CAMGerlach on 2018-08-12T03:36:37.494298+00:00)

I'm a member of the core dev team of the [Spyder](https://www.spyder-ide.org/) scientific Python IDE. As part of [spyder-ide/spyder-docs#39](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder-docs/issues/39) , I wanted to request that you consider including Spyder in the list of [Who Uses Pygments](http://pygments.org/faq/#who-uses-pygments) in your website FAQ, as Spyder uses Pygments for its syntax highlighting for all supported languages. Thanks for providing such a great tool!

Of course, I'd normally just submit a PR against your repo, but it is obviously quite prohibitive to learn hg (and Bitbucket) for such a relatively trivial change, increasing the time load by orders of magnitude. Therefore, I'd ask that you add the following entry to [faq.rst](https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main/src/default/doc/faq.rst) :

```
* `Spyder <https://www.spyder-ide.org/>`_, the Scientific Python Development Environment, uses pygments for the multi-language syntax highlighting in its `Editor <https://docs.spyder-ide.org/editor.html>`__.
```

Feel free to propose changes or removals to better fit your style and requirements. Thanks!

items.title: Coloring for kotlin generic declaration is inconsistent
items.body:
(Original issue 1456 created by jereksel on 2018-07-01T16:31:48.409084+00:00)

http://pygments.org/demo/6753412/

Only first letter "A" is colored - "B" is not.

Also, ">" it not colored when "<" is.

items.title: Add an Operator.Assignment token to the python lexer
items.body:
(Original issue 1453 created by t-makaro on 2018-06-24T16:48:54.551425+00:00)

I'm currently trying to create a pygments style that can accurately reproduce the syntax highlighting of python in jupyter notebook. Unfortunately, jupyter notebook highlights doesn't highlight assignment operators (```=, +=, /=, %= *=,...```) like it does for all other operators (except also equality ```==```).

items.title: python 3.6 f-string prefix not recognized
items.body:
(Original issue 1452 created by t-makaro on 2018-06-24T01:46:34.574468+00:00)

'u','b','r','rb','br' (and their capitalized variants) are parsed by the Python 3 lexer as ```Token.Literal.String.Affix```.


'f','rf','fr' (and their capitalized variants) are parsed as ```Token.Name```.


To reproduce:
```
from pygments.lexer.python import Python3Lexer
lexer = Python3Lexer()

code1 = 'f"str"'
code2 = 'r"str"'
print(list(lexer.get_tokens(code1)))
print(list(lexer.get_tokens(code2)))
```
code2 tokenizes fine, but code 1 tokenizes wrongly.

items.title: Could not lex literal_block as "py3tb"
items.body:
(Original issue 1450 created by enov on 2018-06-22T12:26:16.270176+00:00)

I attached the traceback example. It looks like the lexer can not parse "    base_image=base_image, flavor_name=self.args.flavor) as self.instance:", in particular due to the trailing ":".
